title: disruption-expected-during-four-months-of-pipeline-work-near-morham
story: Five kilometres of pipeline will run from Cockles Brae, south of Haddington, to the Morham crossroads.The new pipe will, says Scottish Water, improve the reliability and resilience of the water supply network for customers in the local area and the wider network.The pipe will run through fields, a burn and across roads, replacing an old nine-inch steel pipe which has come to the end of its le.The work sees Scottish Water Alliance partner Caledonia Water Alliance in stripping soil from the route before cutting a trench for the new pipeline.During the work, which is expected to take about four months, there will be some short periods of local road closures and residents in these areas will be kept informed, says Scottish Water.Scottish Waterrsquos Scott Fraser said: ldquoThis new pipeline will ensure that customers can continue to enjoy a reliable supply of clear, fresh drinking water.

title: rocket-firm-hopes-to-test-engines-at-former-power-station-site
story: Skyrora has revealed it has identied part of the old Cockenzie Power Station site as a location for its test site.The company, which describes itself as a launch vehicle development company with aims to cater for the growing demand to send small satellites into space, is expected to apply for planning permission from East Lothian Council within the next few months.It held a public consultation on its proposals at the Port Seton Centre today .The Courier revealed last August that Skyrora were looking at East Lothian sites, with the former power station one of the possibilities it was considering to test its rocket engines.Skyrora said that the engine testing would not involve the launching of rockets from the site but would require fuel to be stored on-site to fire up the engines.The UK Space Agency announced that it was investing millions of pounds in a site in Sutherland as the new home of the UKrsquos first spaceport for launching rockets.Skyrora said it was looking for an engine test site within an hour of its Edinburgh offices to give it a local base.It said it had identied part of the former power station site, which was bought by East Lothian Council last year, for its tests.The area being put forward for the site is part of the old coal store.Skyrora said: ldquoThe site will be protected, and special measures will be undertaken to control down the noise impacts to acceptable levels and minimal-period test events.Last year it was revealed that Glasgow produced more space satellites than any other city outside of the USA.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe have been in discussions with Skyrora about the possibility of a temporary lease of land for activities based around engine testing.ldquoA planning application would need to be submitted by Skyrora and considered in due course.

title: dog-walkers-surprise-at-coming-across-octopus-on-beach-at-musselburgh
story: Shona Grieve, , from Longniddry, who now lives in the Fisherrow area, was taking her two-year-old white German shepherd Ivy for her regular walk on the beach when she saw the dead creature.She said: "I was walking at the Fisherrow end of the beach beside the the bowling green."I had thrown Ivys ball and walked to where the ball landed and saw the octopus."I walk the beach every day, sometimes three times a day, with Ivy. In all the years of living by the sea, I have never seen an octopus before. So for me it was a very unusual find. Ivy was a bit curious of it too but more interested in her ball to be fair."She added: "I kept ing to it, to convince myself it was dead which it definitely was."The sea was far out but to reassure myself I managed to put it in a pool of water. This was early on and there was nobody  about to show so I took a picture."I have since been told it is getting more common to find them. I had never seen one before ndash my only rare sighting on the beach was when I was a child and found a small pool of seahorses."An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: "The lesser octopus is not that common but they do turn up occasionally, cast up especially after a storm or following prolonged rough weather."Live specimens have also been found in rock pools at the lowest part of the beach."

title: man-gets-scotlands-oldest-hydro-electric-pump-working-after-100-years
story: While across the country new hydropower schemes are helping to feed the revolution in renewables and clean energy, in a hut beside a babbling burn on an estate near Dundee, the forerunner of them all is efficiently and calmly still going about its business.Just as the rest of us might use the garden hut to store the family bikes, a few tools, the lawnmower and maybe mouldy camping gear, Duncan Stewart throws open the door to his workshop to reveal Scotlandrsquos oldest working hydropower Turgo water turbine.Read more:Scottish beauty spot used in James Bond film threatened by major hydro electricity projectInstalled in  ndash just weeks after the first hp Turgo was fitted at Invergeldie Lodge, near Crieff ndash Mr Stewartrsquos personal kW hydropower system is not only generating energy to heat and provide hot water for his five-bedroom house in Burnside of Duntrune, therersquos even enough left over for him to sell on to the National Grid.As a result, Mr Stewart and his we Pat not only live virtually energy bill-free thanks to the turbine, but they also derive some tax-free income from it.ldquoIt is remarkable to think that something installed  years ago is working so well, said Mr Stewart, . ldquoAs a result of it, most of our heating is free, it heats our water and powers a log splitter that provides me with logs for my wood-burning stove that keeps us warm in winter. Itrsquos not just saving us money, itrsquos making money too.Duncan Stewart with the hydropower turbine, which is generating energy after being installed in .The engineering treasure draws its water from the nearby Fithie Burn, which was dammed by workmen using shovels, horses and carts in the months after the First World War.However, water-driven power at the site dates back even earlier ndash to more than  years ago, when there was a mill with a water wheel in the area.The ft high, ft long turbine was originally installed in a workshop serving Duntrune Estate, powering a large circular saw and sending electricity to Duntrune House, nearby Craighill House and Burnside House, the former estate managerrsquos home.When the Stewarts moved to Burnside House almost  years ago, the turbine was still providing electricity to the property ndash albeit via a quickly dismantled hazardous DC connection ndash alongside a mains connection.However, it eventually ground to a halt and was mothballed while the couple opted for more ldquomodern mains supply electricity and an oil-fired range cooker and boiler.It lay rusting until Mr Stewart met television presenter and engineer Lieutenant-Colonel Dick Strawbridge at an event and happened to mention the turbine lurking in his shed.ldquoHe said, lsquoget it fixed, it could be your pensionrsquo, recalled Mr Stewart.Read more:Energy giant plans hefty investment in windfarms and car chargers in ScotlandInspired, he dusted grime from the rusty turbinersquos nameplate and discovered it was a Turgo turbine, manufactured by Cumbria-based Gilbert Gilkes  Gordon Ltd. Papers related to its commission and invoices confirmed it had been installed in  ndash the same year the revolutionary turbine was designed by Eric Crewdson, who had outlined its features while serving in the trenches of the war.Crewdson conceived the idea of a side-entry impulse turbine capable of running at twice the speed of a Pelton water-wheel turbine, with a higher efficiency across a broad flow range.Within months of ing from the war, his concept had been developed and the first Turgo turbine installed at a property in Crieff.However, it is no longer operational ndash making the Stewartsrsquo refurbished and repainted turbine the oldest operational example version of its type in Scotland.The refurbishment was carried out by the original manufacturers, while Mr Stewart set about removing a build-up of silt from the burn.He added: ldquoThe turbinersquos governor alone, which controls the flow of water and is a beautul piece of engineering, must have weighed half a tonne ndash the new one only weighs around half a pound. Now it all works beautully.The savings ndash and earnings ndash have been signicant. Hydropower is used to heat the propertyrsquos water and radiators, enabling the Stewarts to reduce oil consumption, as well as powering the log splitter to feed the stove. ldquoI now use about , to , litres of oil when a house this size would normally require , litres, Mr Stewart added, ldquowhile I get paid for whatever energy is generated regardless of how much actually goes to the Grid.ldquoItrsquos now part of our le.The only downside, he adds, isa dry spell hits and the local farmers opt to use additional local water to irrigate their crops, leaving an insufficient flow to power the system.Hydropower has recently surged in popularity, with dozens of community-run schemes now either in operation or in the planning stages.Hannah Smith, senior policy manager at Scottish Renewables, said: ldquoHydropower is one of Scotlandrsquos great unsung heroes, using our notorious wet weather to provide  per cent of Scotlandrsquos gross electricity demand while reducing the carbon emissions which cause climate change.ldquoMr and Mrs Stewartrsquos turbine is one of Scotlandrsquos oldest, and the fact it is still in service in its th year demonstrates how hydro delivers subsidy-free power long after support provided by government has ceased.She added that the Scottish Renewables Hydro Conference, in Perth on May , is set to explore further ways to ensure hydropower technologyrsquos role in the future energy landscape, particularly in wake of the closure of the Feed-in Tarf scheme earlier this month.

title: neil-mackay-five-key-issues-the-yes-movement-must-address-if-it-wants-to-win-well
story: The Yes movement, which in  was vibrant, optimistic and positive, has become typied by marching and shouting. Therersquos a sense that it has degenerated into a st century Grand Old Duke of York. People parade around towns waving Saltires, but to what avail  Whorsquos being convinced  Which minds are being changed :European election results can help Nicola Sturgeon in push for Scottish independenceEven worse than the gesture politics of pointless parades is the dominance of ugly voices among the grassroots. Itrsquos asthe tide went out after the first referendum ndash taking with it the upbeat, the persuasive, the intelligent, the charismatic ndash leaving behind the abusive, the vulgar, the reactionary, the dumb.Instead of the broad spectrum of informed voices and big ideas of , wersquore left with well-meaning marchers going nowhere, and internet trolls in their basements.Many of the problems stem from the vacuum left after defeat in  ndash the base wanted to keep on, but the SNP leadership chose slow, pragmatic, managerial politics. Whorsquod blame them  The SNP is a political party which wants to win office. It had to keep throwing red meat to the base with cries of ldquoindy is coming, while trying to maintain electoral appeal beyond independence voters.There are five key issues the Yes movement must look to ithopes to win independence well. The first is the tone of debate. Before the last referendum, many voters inherently distrustful of nationalism were brought over to Yes because it seemed open and embracing, it offered an alternative to failed Westminster. Progressives and centrists, and even some on the right, found a comfortable home as Yes voters. There was still a brittle, nasty online presence but it seemed of little intellectual importance.However, today, it appears asthis shrill minority is the dominant voice. The table seating needs readjustingtherersquos to be success. Put these petulant ldquoshouty people at the back of the room.This isnrsquot about silencing voices, they are free to say what they please, but those in leadership positions must speak up against this fringe which repels those considering a Yes vote. Stop following these people on social media, stop amplying their nasty messages ndash especiallyyoursquore in elected office.Which takes us to our second point ndash outreach. The Yes movement must once again start chasing voters and not talking to itself. Woo undecideds. Woo Unionists. Woo everyone. Self-congratulatory backslapping does nothing. Waving a Saltire in the face of Unionists wonrsquot win votes. Marching around a town wonrsquot change anyonersquos mind.Itrsquos not just that many in the base of whatrsquos left of the Yes movement arenrsquot attracting enough new voters to their side, some are wilfully deterring newcomers. The use of the derogatory term ldquoYoonto describe Unionists is guaranteed to offend and repel. Do some really believe insulting people and laughing at them will convert anyone  If MI wanted to cook up an intelligence operation to undermine Scottish independence they could do no better than many of the biggest online voices who claim to back Yes.A banner was unveiled outside the SNP conference at the weekend saying ldquoEngland get out of Scotland. We donrsquot need those who would try to make independence ugly. Scotland isnrsquot occupied. England isnrsquot an enemy. The banner was by a member of Scottish Resistance. Resisting who exactly  English paratroopers over Peebles  Get a le and get out of the way of people who really want to change this country for the better.:Scottish independence poll: One in five Scots back Nicola Sturgeons Indyref planItrsquos even worse when those not part of the lunatic fringe embarrass. Also at the SNP conference was Dave Thompson, former SNP MSP and chair of Voices for Scotland which is meant to be an ldquoinclusive" Yes campaign group. Mr Thompson used Gaelic and Scots to introduce himself to delegates and added: ldquoApologies to those who do not have the two proper languages of Scotland. Really  It may have been a joke, but is this what we want to hear from a party which says it welcomes EU residents Thirdly, the Yes movement needs to get real over dficult questions. Voters have been exhausted and terried by Brexit. The SNP grassroots may want to scrap the pound, but itrsquos not a policy thatrsquos going to win new Yes voters ndash it will only scare them. When it comes to independence, undecideds are now worried about trade deals with England and a possible hard border. Brexit has made independence more dficult as itrsquos raised more questions.No-one sane wants independence to pile on more ision after Brexit. Thatrsquos why the creation of Citizensrsquo Assemblies, to work out the future of Scotland, is a welcome move. Take these big frightening questions directly to the people and to experts and letrsquos hear the evidence and the truth. Momentous change needs rigorous analysis and adult honesty.Fourthly, independence is too big for the SNP alone ndash Scotland is not the SNPrsquos country, it is the peoplersquos, and Citizensrsquo Assemblies can help us work out what is in all our best interests when it comes to our constitutional future, rather than in the narrow interests of one party. It must be said over and over again that a Yes vote is not an SNP vote.I want to see Scotland independent but I want to know the full hard truths before I vote again ndash and I fervently do not want to see this country ided against itself.Perhaps, then, the fth issue is the hardest for many Yes voters to accept ndash that a mere win in any second referendum is not enough, maybe we need to set ourselves a  per cent margin before enacting change. It would be bold, it would ease fears among Unionists, it would show that the Yes movement cares about the country, not just itself, and many may find that appealing and attractive.Most importantly, do we want Scotland in the wake of a close win for independence ndash like a - margin ndash to go through the pain and hatred Britain has already gone through with Brexit  I want independence ndash but I do not want that.Neil Mackay is Scotlandrsquos Columnist of the Year.

title: theresa-may-mindful-of-public-mood-and-wants-to-wrap-up-cross-party-talks-next-week-one-way-or-the-other
story: Now into their fth week, the discussions have been ldquoserious and constructive, according to No , and yesterdayrsquos meeting appeared to be the most successful to date.David Lidington, Theresa Mays de facto deputy, described that meeting as "productive," saying he had been "encouraged" by a sense from both sides about the "need to inject greater urgency" into the talks.:Brexit extension: What happens next  Will Theresa May quit  Heres everything you need to knowLabourrsquos Sue Hayman, the Shadow Environment Secretary, was equally upbeat, saying there had been a "really constructive discussion" as the two parties were "getting much more into the nuts and bolts of the detail".Nonetheless, serious dferences still exist on a number of issues, not least that of a customs union, Labourrsquos official policy.Jeremy Hunt, the Foreign Secretary, warned that the Government risked losing Tory supportit agreed to a customs union plan.He told BBC Radio s Today programme: "If we were proposing, which I very much hope we dont, to sign up to the customs union, then there is a risk that you would lose more Conservative MPs than you would gain Labour MPs."If, on the other hand, it was something dferent, then the result could be dferent as well."A Cabinet colleague has told The Herald the cross-party talks are doomed as Jeremy Corbyn believes, politically, he has more to gain from them collapsing.However, others disagree, believingthe Labour leader agreed a compromise this would split the Tories and boost Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party. Equally though, it would also split Labour as Mr Corbyn is unlikely to put any cross-party deal to a second referendum which most of Labourrsquos grassroots want.:Theresa May urged to put fight against climate change on war footing by cross-party politiciansThe Government has to raty WAB for the UK to leave the EU. Ministerial sources have said the legislation will have to be introduced after this weekrsquos English local elections ndash when the Tories are expecting to get a drubbing - and before the scheduled European elections on May  ndash when they are expected to get another drubbing.This means the likelihood is WAB will be introduced next week or the week after.Any deal with Labour would have to include a cast-iron guarantee that it would back WAB through all its parliamentary stages.Todayrsquos weekly Cabinet discussed Brexit and the state of play regarding the Con-Lab talks. Julian Lewis, the Chief Whip, updated colleagues on the passage of WAB.Theresa Mayrsquos spokesman declined to get into specics about the meeting but said: ldquoThere is an understanding on the need to make progress on delivering Brexit the way to leave the EU with a deal is via securing safe passage of the Withdrawal Agreement Bill[WAB]. What I am saying today will reflect the understanding that the Government needs to be making progress to deliver what the British people voted for.Askedthe Government had calculated how many parliamentary days it needed to get the legislation through, he explained how a great deal of work had already gone into preparing WAB but suggested no one could be precise about how many days the bill would take.However, the spokesman stressed there was a ldquofull understanding throughout Cabinet of the need to make progress as soon as possible and that the British public want Parliament to ldquoget on with it.One senior Whitehall source has made clear: ldquoThere is urgency and there is no point in continuingtalks are not in a productive state we donrsquot feel that is the case at the moment but obviously there can be no open-ended duration.Askedthe Government was hoping to wrap things up by the end of this week, he made clear no specic date was being set but again stressed the urgency to make progress as quickly as possible.More talks between the parties are due in the coming days but there is a firm recognition within Whitehall that after several weeks of talks the public wants things to be brought to a conclusion one way or another.

title: mackay-accused-of-being-in-full-retreat-on-new-currency
story: The Scottish Tories claimed the Finance Secretary was in ldquofull retreat after he emphasised the caveats attached to his partyrsquos new policy, rather than its merits.Mr Mackay also stressed the SNPrsquos proposals involving keeping the pound initially, and Holyrood would decidethere should be a change, subject to six stringent tests.He said: ldquoOur position is clear. Until a new currency can be safely and established in the interests of the whole economy, the currency of an independent Scotland should continue to be the pound sterling.ldquoIt will be for an independent Scottish Parliament when the time is right -there is that change - based on the right economic position for Scotland.:Iain Macwhirter: Therersquos no need for the SNP to take a pounding over currency issueDelegates to the SNPrsquos spring conference voted on Saturday by  to  to establish a new currency ldquoas soon as practicable, subject to six tests.The vote was a surprise defeat from Nicola Sturgeon and Mr Mackay, who had advocated a more gradual approach, with no new currency for at least a decade, in keeping with the SNPs Growth Commission.The policy sht offered the First Ministerrsquos unionist opponents, including newly ed Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson, a ready target to attack the Yes movement.In an urgent question at Holyrood, Labour MSP James Kelly asked Mr Mackay what impact a new currency would have on business.:SNP members support new currency as soon as practicableMr Mackay said: ldquoFirstly, our proposals are to keep the pound in the immediate term, and an SNP government will take steps necessary to enable the Scottish Parliament to authorise the preparation of a Scottish currency as soon as practicable after independence.ldquoThe Sustainable Growth Commission established by the First Minister in her capacity as SNP leader produced a detailed report on the financial, economic and regulatory requirements necessary for the transition to an independent currency.ldquoIt engaged extensively with businesses in developing its recommendations. It recommended the introduction of six tests to guide that transition, one of which is the financial requirements of Scottish residents and businesses.ldquoThose tests were back by SNP conference on Saturday. Our position is clear. Until a new currency can be safely and established in the interests of the whole economy, the currency of an independent Scotland should continue to be the pound sterling.Mr Kelly said the SNP wanted to drop the pound immediately, devaluing savings, and would make Scottish families and business ldquosignicantly worse off.Mr Mackay, who was on the Growth Commission, said he was ldquodelighted the currency resolution he co-authored was passed - after activists added ldquoas soon as practicable.He said: ldquoWe have set out, in terms of currency, the position that we continue with the pound. Wersquove set out the tests that will guide our decisions.ldquoIt will be for an independent Scottish Parliament when the time is right -there is that change - based on the right economic position for Scotland.ldquoAnd those tests - fiscal sustainability, central bank credibility, financial requirements of Scottish residents and business, sufficiency of foreign exchange and financial reserves, fit to trade and investment patterns, and correlation of economic and trade cycle - these are sensible tests that would guide such a decision.Tory MSP Murdo Fraser said: ldquoItrsquos only been three days since the vote at his conference and already the cabinet secretary is in full retreat from the position set out at that conference.He asked what work had been done on the ldquoextra transaction costs for Scots firms trading with the rest of the UK - Scotlandrsquos biggest export market - using a dferent currency.Mr Mackay said: ldquoWe will be keeping the pound on independence, and of course we can build our options as an independent country.ldquoWersquove set out the tests that we would apply to any potential change of currency.ldquoWersquove set out our preferred position. And wersquove also shown, really importantly, how our economic policies would be enhancedwe had the powers of independence.ldquoThat would grow our economy, deliver greater fairness and empower us to make the right decisions by the people of Scotland.In response to SNP MSP Bruce Crawford, Mr Mackay agreed the currency would remain the pound after a Yes vote and only change when an independent parliament decided that.ldquoOur policy is that we will support a change as soon as it can done safely and securely in the interests of the country, the economics of the country, when the time is right.Mr Mackayrsquos comments followed more criticism of the plan to ditch the pound.A former member of and an adviser to the partyrsquos Growth Commission both questioned the move, saying it could jeopardise peoplersquos savings and was not a priority.Richard Marsh, an external adviser to the Growth Commission, warned savers and householders could he hammeredthe new currency has less value than sterling.In , the Scottish Governmentrsquos own Fiscal Commission Working Group warned a new currency was a ldquosignicant undertaking in the short-term, though not unprecedented, and Scotland would need to ldquore-denominate all domestic wages, prices and contracts.Ms Sturgeonrsquos special advisers were unable to say at the weekend whether a new currency would be pegged to sterling - with the Scottish pound worth the same as a UK pound, for example - or float on the international money markets, and potentially be devalued.Mr Marsh said devaluation could wipe out yearsrsquo of savings and leave , householders trapped in negative equity, as their mortgages were recalculated in the new currency.He told the Scottish Daily Mail: ldquoThe Scottish Government may seek to absorb some of this risk to protect mortgage and asset values by pegging the currency.ldquoBut [given] this could be at the cost of public services and delivery, this would be a dficult decision for any new administration to make.ldquoIf Scotland took a lsquobig bangrsquo approach with a new currency set up shortly after a vote for independent, then it would mean businesses, iniduals and the Government would need to take account of movements in exchange rates between the newly established Scottish pound and sterling.Dan Macdonald, a former member of the Growth Commission, said currency was ldquoalmost irrelevant compared to economic growth and ldquosecondary in the independence debate.He said: ldquoWe need plans for the economy over the next five to ten years. That is more important than any one issue, including the constitutional question - we need to build the economy first.Financier Peter de Vink, a friend of Alex Salmond who backed Yes in , said a fledgling independent Scottish currency would be a magnet for speculators.The director of Edinburgh Financial and General Holdings said the result could be worse than Black Wednesday in , when speculators made millions betting on sterlingrsquos devluation, sending interest rates soaring.He said: ldquoThe pound was devalued by  per cent and that was in Britain - Scotland is a tenth of the size, so it would be even more of a problem. It would be devastating.ldquoIt is cloud cuckoo land stuffthey think they can do it. I thought there would be a little more brain power.ldquo[At] the last referendum, we avoided the currency issue as much as we could because we all knew it would be the most dficult thing.ldquoTalking about a currency is all wishful thinkingyou havenrsquot got a strong economy, and Scotland is not going to have a stronger economyScotland continues to have higher taxes than the rest of the United Kingdom.An SNP spokesperson said: "Scotland will keep the pound immediately after independence."The SNPs policy is to make a managed and responsible transition to an independent currency, only when it is safe, secure and practicable to do so."

Robert Gordon dropped two to th, Stirling dropped three to rdand Abertay dropped four to rd.St Andrews is also top in the UK for student satisfaction in the new guide, recognising the exceptional quality of learning and teaching and overall student experience on offer at the university.In separate listings covering  subjects, St Andrews features in the top ten for  subjects, topping four, making it one of just five institutions in the UK to be top of more than two subject tables ndash Glasgow came top in seven subjects.St Andrews is just one Scottish success story in the new guide. Edinburghrises seven places, while Glasgowjumps six, meaning Scotlandrsquos top three universities all appear in the top  of the main table.:Scarlet gowns of St Andrews University worn "to discourage student vice"St Andrewsrsquo principal Professor Sally Mapstone told the Scotsman: ldquoItrsquos an honour to be top in Scotland in such a competitive and high-quality field north of the Border. These results are a reflection of the commitment of our staff and students to the highest standards of teaching, research, study and student experience.ldquoIt is, however, vital, at a time of global change and the shydismantling of traditional alliances, that St Andrews and other Scottish universities are able to continue to compete on a world stage.ldquoOur universities are one of this countryrsquos great assets. Maintaining the brand of Scottish higher education overseas and ensuring that the world knows that Scotland is open to talented students of all nationalities and backgrounds is now one of our greatest challenges.

title: home-office-criticised-over-glasgow-asylum-seeker-lock-change-obligation
story: The Mears Group, who will replace Sercoin September, could not confirm the practice would not be used by their staff to remove asylum seekers from their properties across the city.In August, Serco were heavily criticised for their decision to issue lock change notices to asylum seekers living in Glasgow.:Serco loses housing contract after threatening to evict Glasgow asylum seekersA legal bid to prevent those who have exhausted appeal rights and been found to have no right to remain in the UK being evicted without a court order was dismissed in April.Despite this, Serco have not continued on with their plans to issue evictions notices to those living under the care of both them and the Home Office.However, fresh concerns have now been raised after it emerged that the Mears Group will be "contractually obliged" to carry out evictions on behalf of the Home Office come September.Around  people across the city could be affected by the Home Office policy, which could leave vulnerable men and women destitute and without shelter.Reported to be under particular threat are women, with no emergency accommodation available to them.A spokesperson for the Asylum Seeker HousingProject said: "We are disappointed the new provider seems to be suggesting they will just continue to follow Sercorsquos discredited lock change eviction procedures."We were hoping Mears would accept this practice is abhorrent and has no place in a civilized society but unfortunately it appears once again profit triumphs over morality in the private sector."When asked about whether the use of lock-change evictions would be used by Mears under Home Office instruction, both parties declined to comment.Mears are now being encouraged to engage with the council in ensuring those most at risk are supported throughout the asylum process.Green Councillor Kim Long, who sits on the Asylum Seeker Strategic Forum, said: "Vulnerable new Glaswegians should not be living under the threat of eviction. How can you deal with complex legal mattersyou are making survival decisions to get through each day "We need a one-stop shop where people can access legal support alongside emergency accommodation. The council has agreed to explore on this, but the continued eviction threat makes clear this work is urgently needed.:Campaigners raise fears over fresh Glasgow asylum seeker evictions after court rulingRefugee charities have echoed calls for Mears to engage with the council, claiming they must conform to human rights standards, including in the "repossession of asylum accommodation.Sabir Zazai, CEO of the Scottish Refugee Council, said: "Mears Group have the opportunity to take a dferent and humane approach in partnership with the city council and its refugee sector to ensure no one is rendered homeless here via the Home office asylum process."We urge them to do that publicly by committing to be an integral part of a new city partnership based on zero tolerance of asylum destitution in Glasgow. That would be the best way to move on from the Home office and Serco evictions debacle of last summer.Members of the tenants union Living Rent have also condemned Mears contractual obligation to carry out evictions on behalf of the Home Office, saying contractors can "issue an eviction at the click of an email" with "no regard for peoples lives".A spokesperson added: "We are outraged to hear that the future accommodation contractors and the Home Office are not attempting to find a solution to the crisis at hand."A Home Office spokesperson said: ldquoThe Home Office takes the wellbeing of asylum seekers and the local communities in which they live extremely seriously.ldquoWe will continue to work closely with local authorities and partners to ensure that those who have no right to be in the UK leave their accommodation in a safe and secure way.ldquoWe are working with Glasgow City Council to agree and implement a support advice referral process for those at risk of potential eviction.The Mears Group declined to comment.

title: glasgow-city-council-leader-susan-aitken-reported-to-watchdog-for-stirring-sectarian-divide
story: Frank McAveety, the head of the local authorityrsquos Labour group, has lodged a complaint against the SNPrsquos Susan Aitken with the Commissioner for Ethical Standards, claiming she has broken the councillorsrsquo code of conduct.The complaint relates to a report in The Sun newspaper that Ms Aitken posted a picture of Mr McAveety to a private Facebook group for SNP councillors.It included the comment: ldquoIf anyone feels like getting these nice photos of Frank McAveety enjoying hospitality in the Rangers directorsrsquo box out therehellipIt would appear that in July , at the height of the Fanzone controversy, the SNP leader of Glasgow CC sought to belittle her predecessor Celtic fan for attending a Rangers game at Ibrox. Can @SusaninLangside confirm  pic CBcaApcxmdash Adam Tomkins MSPApril , Mr McAveety claims this was an attempt to ldquostir up a sectarian ide but an SNP spokesman told The Sun the post was a ldquojoke.:Agenda by Susan Aitken: Glasgow intends to take a strong stance on marchesFormer Glasgow City Council leader Mr McAveetyrsquos letter states: ldquoIn context, these comments came amid outrage over a decision to withdraw support for a fan zone at Ibrox Football Stadium, leading to claims of political interference in a quasi-judicial decision.It continues: ldquoThe comments, as reported with the images, indicate that the leader of the council wished members of her group to circulate this image, in an apparent attempt to stir up a sectarian ide on this issuehellip.ldquoThese comments and this coordination fall very signicantly short of the behaviour that should be expected of anyone in public le.:Agenda: Putting Glasgow to the fore on the global stageHe claims they breach two sections of the code of conduct relating to respecting colleagues and treating them with courtesy, including on social media.Mr McAveety said: ldquoIn response to legitimate criticism, Susan Aitken has sought to stir up a sectarian ide that our city is trying to consign to the past.ldquoThat is flat-out unacceptable. The leader of the council should reflect on her behaviour and whether this is the standard that Glaswegians expect.ldquoI have asked the Standards Commissioner to investigate this behaviour because I do not believe that it is fitting for behaviour for an elected member.A spokesman for the SNPrsquos Glasgow group said: ldquoEveryone understood Susanrsquos post was a joke, as evidenced by the fact nobody did anything with it.

title: arts-controversy-turner-prize-questioned-over-choosing-stagecoach-as-its-main-sponsor
story: This years prize short list includes artists Lawrence Abu Hamdan, Helen Cammock, Oscar Murillo and Tai Shani, who has been short listed in part for her exhibition at last years Glasgow International festival.Usually it is the art in the short list which provides instant controversy, not the sponsor.However, todaythere has been criticism of the organisers for choosing Stagecoach as a sponsor: in , Souter have poundm to a campaign to keep the Section  law in Scotland, the failed Keep the Clause campaign.Peter Tatchell, the gay rights activist, said he was surprised and disappointed by the decision.The choice of sponsor dominated the press launch for the short listed artists.Mr Tatchell told The Daily : "Surely there must be other less tainted potential sponsors  The arts is an LGBT-friendly profession and should not be colluding with companies whose leaders support homophobic discrimination."The questions over the sponsorship overshadowed the announcement of the short list for the prize, which gives pound, to the winner.Last years Turner Prize was won by Scottish artist Charlotte Prodger with her film, shot on an iPhone, about "queer identity" and her experience of coming out as gay in rural Scotland.When the press conference to unveil this years shortlist was askedanyone had considered the choice of sponsorship a bad idea, "there was an awkward silence", according to reports.Tate Britain director Alex Farquharson said that picking a sponsor "is very much a matter for the hosting venue".Stagecoach South East is one of  locally managed companies within Stagecoach Group, which is based in Perth.Pressed further, she added: "We have to take on board a whole range of issues when deciding our sponsorship."In this instance we decided that the role that the company plays in the area is very important."Mr Farquharson later told the media: "I think thats probably enough on sponsors."A statement from the Tate late said that local sponsors were vital to the exhibition being staged at venues outside London.Stagecoach issued a statement, which said: "Stagecoach does not tolerate discrimination or harassment of any kind based on disability, gender, gender re-assignment, sexual orientation, religion, believe, age, nationality, race or ethnic origin."Our Stagecoach culture values transparency, ersity, and respect."We expect our employees to commit to doing the right thing, to respect other iniduals at all times and treat them with dignity and thoughtfulness."The winner will be announced on  December.Next year the prize willto Tate Britain.

title: pmqs-sketch-tories-jeer-and-nationalists-jeer-as-pm-wishes-england-and-scotlands-union-happy-birthday
story: The culprit who raised the Brexit ghost was the Highland champion himself, bemoaning how the benighted UK Government had not matched the enlightened Scottish Governmentrsquos promise to extend free EU student fees to .Thezza pointed out, to a rumble of Tory indignation, the Scottish Government had announced ldquoEU students can have free tuition up to  but English students will have to pay.After Ian Blackford accused the PM of being ldquoblinded by ideology, he pointed out how under a no-deal scenario the Tory Government was planning on curbing EU visas to three years the problem for European students was Scottish university courses were four years.But the head girl couldnrsquot let the chief Nat get away with his ideology quip and snapped: ldquoThis is from the SNP!She arguedthe SNP were so worried about Scottish students, it should spend more time improving education and less ldquoobsessing about independence.Underlining the Con-Lab talks are at a sensitive stage, Jezza didnrsquot even mention the B-word but focused on Englandrsquos local elections, complaining about how ldquothings are getting worse under the terrible Tories.The chief comrade accused Thezza of failing to tackle her famous ldquoburning injustices and complained things were so bad under Conservative rule ldquole expectancy in Britain is falling for the first time since . Of course, it could just be down to Brexit.John Lamont, the Berwickshire champion, reminded anyone who needed reminding, May  was the Unionrsquos th birthday and that, to Tory shouts of delight, most Scots felt it had served Scotland well.Maggie May took up the cudgel and, to Conservative cheers and Nationalist jeers, declared: ldquoIt is time the SNP stopped ignoring those millions of Scots who do not want another independence referendum and got on with the day job of focusing on the issues that matter to people such as schools and the economy.Earlier, the PM couldnrsquot stop congratulating MPs who had taken part in the London Marathon, including her own PPS the West Aberdeenshire MP Andrew Bowie.The -year-old posted the fastest time of any of the  MPs who took part an impressive ::. Indeed, he pipped Mr Lamont to the post by just two minutes an achievement the latter acknowledged, promising colleagues he would ldquotrain much harder next year.Mr Bowiersquos performance just goes to show: Downing St can get something over the line.

title: blair-cautions-may-over-huawei-decision-saying-he-would-need-lot-of-convincing-it-is-right-move
story: In an interview with The Herald, the former Prime Minister described the UK Governmentrsquos decision of being of ldquohuge strategic importance to the country.He explained: ldquoYoursquove got to be extremely careful because you have to go into that decision with a great deal of care because itrsquos a massive decision.Askedhe was in favour of the Governmentrsquos move, Mr Blair replied: ldquoI would need a lot of convincing on this because it is of fundamental importance.ldquoIrsquom, by the way, in favour of a good relationship with ChinahellipBut the fact of Chinese power and the system is dferent from ours in a fundamental way, you have got to be extremely careful, he added.In the Commons, Mrs May was accused by a senior Conservative of running the risk of "nesting a dragon" and ignoring alliesrsquo warnings over allowing Huawei into the construction of the UKs G communications network.Tom Tugendhat, who chairs the Commons Foreign Affairs Committee, raised concerns over the Chinese tech giants potential involvement in the project during PMQs and branded the decision "frankly extraordinary" given warnings from America and Australia.The PM said the Governmentrsquos decisions were supported by a "hard-headed, technically informed assessment of the risk" and maintained the UK worked closely with allies on security matters.Mrs May has given the green light for Huawei to provide "non-core" elements of the UK network, overriding concerns of a number of senior ministers and foreign allies.Rob Strayer, a senior US official, has warned Americarsquos intelligence-sharing with other countries would have to be re-evaluatedBritain used Huawei to build its G network. He made clear any such role for the firm posed an "unacceptable risk" to security.In the Commons, Mr Tugendhat warned about Britain ldquonesting a dragon in its critical national infrastructure by allowing Huawei to help build the countrys cyber network."This decision is frankly extraordinary given the advice of the National Security Agency in the US and the Australian Signals Directorate, declared the Kent MP."Could the Prime Minister perhaps explain why she feels ignoring two of our closest intelligence allies and putting in danger a -year intelligence-sharing relationship that has underpinned the security of the UK is worth it for Chinese commercial gain "Mrs May insisted the UK Government took decisions supported by a hard-headed, technically informed assessment of risk. She stressed security issues were discussed closely with allies."We have put in place a review of the G supply chain to ensure we have a secure and resilient roll-out of G and the decisions of that review will be announced in due course.The PM added: "The priorities we have in relation to the future of telecommunications are stronger cyber security practices, greater resilience in telecoms networks and ersity in the market. And that drives our thinking."

title: honour for football manager
story: The first ever manager of the Scotland national football team is to have a road named after him in his home town of Kintore.Andy Beattie, who was born in , was remembered at Tuesday’s meeting of Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee when it formally named a new road at Kintore’s Midmill Business Park ‘Andy Beattie Way’.Soon after he began working at the Inverurie Loco Works, Andy joined the Works football team where he established himself as an accomplished full-back before moving to English First Division club Preston North End in March .Andy made his Scotland debut two years after joining Preston and in the six games he played for the national side he remained unbeaten.He became Scotland’s first ever manager when he took charge in , managing them briefly at the  World Cup in Switzerland and then again from -.He also managed numerous clubs including Nottingham Forest and Wolverhampton Wanderers, while also enjoying a spell as scout for Liverpool.Developers of the business park had originally proposed the name Tofthills Circle for the new street name, but Councillor Glen Reid suggested ‘Andy Beattie Way’ as an alternative – a move backed by councillors Martin Ford and Dominic Lonchay.Committee chair Councillor Fergus Hood said it was a “very appropriate name” and thanked Councillor Reid for liaising with Andy’s family who had formally agreed to the use of his name.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Head to Inverurie this weekend for some wedding inspiration"  Wedding Weekend toto Inverurie for second year viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: iba hosts inverurie business expo
story: The Inverurie Business Associationheld their inaugural Business Expo as part of its Annual General Meeting last week.The meeting was held on Thursday, April  at the Fly Cup Café to an audience from the local business community, councillors and other interested parties from the wider Inverurie area.The Business Expo attracted a range of local businesses to promote their products and services to the IBA AGM attendees. At the AGM, Victoria Withy provided a review of the last  months of IBA activity, and Pete Tyler provided the financial statement of the period. The existing nine IBA committee members all stood for re-election at the meeting. Each of the committees gave a short presentation as to their activities to-date for the IBA which included: Event Management, School Liaison, Marketing, Lobbying and an update from the We Are Inverurie BID Manager, Derek Ritchie.The IBA committee members work voluntarily, to support its members by promoting Inverurie as a great place to do business, to run a business and to be part of a business in, facilitating training, dissemination of information and the provision of networking opportunities for members, and to ensure that the voice of Inverurie’s businesses are heard by local councillors, Aberdeenshire Council, and local MP and MPS on matters that affect the business community.The IBA announced initiatives scheduled for  including further business-focused workshops, a breakfast conference in autumn, a new quarterly IBA newsletter and continued lobbying activities to increase member’s awareness of critical topics that impact Inverurie and an update of the all exciting events that We Are Inverurie have planned.After the meeting, Victoria Withy said: “I am delighted with the number of businesses who exhibited at our inaugural Business Expo, and this initiative is something that we will be doing again to showcase Inverurie businesses, help IBA in promoting Inverurie as a good place to do business.“Looking back over the past year I am delighted with the progress we have made, helping to draw attention to matters that impact local businesses and the town including our feeding back to Aberdeenshire Council on Car Parking, Local Development Plan, dualling of the A and other matters that impact Inverurie.“I want to thank the IBA committee members who volunteer their time to the IBA bringing with them a wealth of professional expertise with which we can better support our members.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: new recycling procedures rolled out across aberdeenshire
story: New procedures are being rolled out across Aberdeenshire Council#s kerbside collection service from this week in an attempt to reduce the contamination of recycling bins with non-recyclable items.The aim is to reduce the amount of recyclates which can’t be processed because they’ve been mixed with non-recyclable materials, helping to avoid sending items to landfill and reducing disposal costs. The council’s Infrastructure Services Committeeapproved the kerbside collection policy and procedures last year, including guidance on how to deal with contaminated bins. Any non-recyclable material placed into the recycling bin is classed as ‘contamination’, which could spoil the recyclates in any load. The recycling reprocessor may then reject whole loads as a result. Any rejected loads of recycling are disposed of at an additional cost to the taxpayer, for which there is no council budget available. Income which they would have generated to invest in services is lost.Collection crews will now visually check each recycling bin for contaminated recycling before emptying as a matter of course – those with severe contamination will not be emptied. Households consistently presenting severely contaminated bins will be offered advice and support to properly separate their waste. Those who ignore that advice could run the risk of their recycling bin being removed.Moderately contaminated bins will be emptied and an orange tag will be attached, providing information to the householder on how to properly use the recycling service. If a bin has not been emptied and tagged explaining why it has not been emptied, it is contaminated and the offending materials must be removed before the next collection. Crews will notto empty a rejected bin until the next scheduled collection day for the same bin.Bins considered to have little or no levels of contaminants will be emptied as normal.Collection crews will keep a record of bins unemptied due to overloading or contamination and this will be checked before a decision is made toto empty any bin reported as a missed collection.For those with a lot of recyclable materials, additional, free recycling bins can be requested by contacting the council’s Wasteline. Additional non-recyclable waste bins may also be authorised where there is a genuine need following a home visit and assessment by a Community Waste Officer. data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Police urge revellers to be safe and responsible viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"The council’s Head of Roads, Waste and Landscape services, Philip McKay, said: “It’s important residents understand how to recycle properly and make best use of the facilities available to them. “Sending waste to landfill costs more than double the amount it costs to recycle and tackling the levels of contamination in kerbside bins is intended to reduce the amount of recyclates sent to landfill.“We will be enforcing the procedures in a staggered rollout, tackling problem routes first. This will allow crews to get used to the new procedures without any severe implications for the collection schedule.”Over half the materials in local non-recyclable waste bins are recyclable through existing services – equating to around , tonnes of recyclable materials being landfilled at a cost of £.million a year.Not only does maximising the value of a material benefit the environment, it also frees up money for other essential council services.Residents are encouraged to get in touch with the Recycling and Waste Aberdeenshire Facebook pagethey are unsure of how to dispose of any material not listed in the A-Z guide.For any recycling and waste related queries, or to request an additional recycling or non-recycling bin, please contact Wasteline.

title: occasional hours licence for brewdog
story: An Aberdeenshire licensing authority has narrowly paved the way for the anticipated opening of BrewDog#s new #, Inverurie bar and restaurant next month.Despite the brewing giants not possessing a provisional licence, Aberdeenshire Central Licensing Board took the highly unusual step of granting two occasional licences to enable it to open in the former Mitchell’s Dairy premises on Market Street.Some  new staff can now be employed at the bar which will see the number of BrewDog employees in Aberdeenshire soar to more than .BrewDog retail director James Brown told the board the firm had made “a huge commitment to Inverurie and Aberdeenshire” and afterwards said he was “delighted” with the decision which will initially allow the bar to operate from May  to .The company’s full licence application is currently being fast-tracked by the council after delays incurred due to the installation of a new data system and subsequent backlog.Under the agreement after a close - vote by licensing board members, the bar has been limited to operating from am to  midnight Sunday to Thursday and from am to am Friday and Saturday but only while former BrewDog Tap Room manager Craig Cargill is on the premises. Off-sales have been approved from am to pm Monday to Sunday.However, among ious conditions imposed by the licensing standards team, it was also agreed that the outdoor space to the rear of the premises will not be utilised by customers until a full licence is granted.The licensing board heard from Audrey Junner of agents Hill Brown Licensing that BrewDog had no intention to trade by way of occasional licences for an extended period of time.She added: “We would like to reassure members that a provisional premises licence has been submitted… for the avoidance of doubt my clients wholly accept that no assumptions can be made about the grant of that provisional licence.“They have undertaken the fit-out works at the business entirely at their own risk.”But licensing standards officer Lisa Gordini reminded the board that while a provisional licence had been applied for, it would not be discussed until the board’s June meeting and could receive representations or objections which could impact on BrewDog’s operation.She maintained there was an argument that the board should not be granting any occasional licences which may “conflict with the consultation process” of the provisional licence application.After considerable debate, board member Robbie Withey proposed refusal of the application, saying the authority expected a six-month consultation period to process applications and that the company – which operates  bars around the world – should have applied sooner.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: pitcairn dominates thainstone breeding sale
story: A Limousin cross British Blue heer and its heer calf sold for the top price at Aberdeen and Northern Marts# annual show and sale of commercial beef breeding cattle at Thainstone, sponsored by East Coast Viners.The animals from regular consignors, Craig and Katreen Malone, Pitcairn, Lochgelly, Cardenden, Fe, sold for £,.Champion in the pre-sale show judged by Will MacDonald, Tormore, Dunbeath and Kris Sutherland, Dunbeath Farms, Dunbeath, this heer was originally bought as a bulling heer from William and David Moir of Moir Livestock, Fraserburgh, while the heer calf is by Lodge Hamlet.The outfit sold for the lead price of £ to Dunbeath Farms, Dunbeath, Caithness.Craig and Katreen also scooped the reserve champion honours with a Limousin cross heer bred by Tom Howden, Stanley Farms. It sold with its bull calf by a Powerhouse sire for £ to DA Manson,  Larel, Halkirk.The second prize Simmental heer and its bull calf from Pitcairn, made £ to Ian Stewart, Reisgill, Lybster, while their champion Simmental heer and its bull calf sold for £ to Dunbeath Farms.Father and son, Charlie and Keith Ogg from Buchaam, Strathdon, received £ for the third prize Limousin heer with heer calf. This was an unregistered pure Limousin with a calf by the British Blue sire, Nochnary Keano.The third prize Simmental heer with heer calf from I and M Keith, Auchtygall, Peterhead, made £ also to Ian Stewart, while the second prize Limousin heer with heer calf from William Law, West Cruichie, Drumblade, Huntly, sold for £ to Donald and James Fraser, Easter Clune, Lethen, Nairn.A heer calf from Danny Leslie, Redhill, Mosstowie, Elgin, won the best Simmental sired calf award and sold with its mother for £ to Brian McIntosh, Mains of Tarryblake, Rothiemay.Aberdeen and Northern Marts’ head of livestock, John Angus, said: “We had an excellent show of heer and calves forward which met a brisk demand.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Overall champion from Mike Massie"  Bonnykelly Charolais tops the trade at Thainstone viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: review praise for local filmmaker
story: A Kemnay filmmaker has received praise for a documentary he made while reporting in Iraq.Dale McEwan has produced a documentary investigating the le-changing consequences of counterfeit medicine in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq.He lts the lid on the governmental and medical disaster and exposes the bigger picture of injustice, a failing health system and conflicts of interest in Kurdistan – Iraq’s so-called “safe haven”.Review website UK Film Review awarded the documentary  stars out of  and the review says:“McEwan has crafted an incisive and concise takedown of governmental corruption through exhaustive research and solid film-making.”Mr McEwan worked on the film for one year while he was a journalist in Kurdistan.He said: “I’m so grateful that the victims’ ongoing struggle for justice has been recognised in this review. Receiving feedback like this is very encouraging and it’s more than I could have hoped for.”The documentary, Stolen Vision - Counterfeit Medicine in Iraqi Kurdistan, is on YouTube.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"IBA committee members Bryan Stewart, Mo Khan, Josh Macrae, Edward Obi, Derek Ritchie, Pete Tyler, Victoria Withy, Debbie Anderson and Hayley Yule"  IBA hosts Inverurie Business Expo viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: thainstone prepares for annual show and sale
story: Aberdeen and Northern Marts# Thainstone Centre is gearing up for its annual show and sale of commercial breeding cattle and pedigree bulls and females next week.The show and sale of heers with calves at foot and other commercial breeding cattle, sponsored by East Coast Viners, will commence on Tuesday, April  with the show in Ring  at am, followed by the sale at am.Judges for the pre-sale show are Will MacDonald, Tormore and Kris Sutherland, Dunbeath Farms.Included in the offering of  breeding cattle is top-quality Simmental cross, Limousin cross and Salers cross heers, with spring-born calves at foot, many with show ring potential.All heers have been selected for their milking and breeding ability.On the same day, the annual show and sale of pedigree bulls and females, sponsored by Ardene Vets, has attracted  bulls and three females.Orkney’s Liam Muir from Upper Onston, will judge the pedigree bulls from am onwards in the Exchange and the sale will commence at .pm in Ring .Forward for sale is  Charolais, nine Limousin, eight Simmental, seven Salers, five Aberdeen-Angus, two British Blue, two Beef Shorthorn and  Gascone.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Vandals strike at Inverurie school viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: anzac day respects paid in orkney 2
story: Those who lost their lives during wartime from Australia and New Zealand have been remembered in a service here in Orkney today, Anzac Day, the national day of remembrance in both those countries.In World War One, a campaign was launched on the Gallipoli Peninsula aimed at the capture of the Dardanelles, and so securing the free passage of shipping to the Black Sea.The campaign was launched on April , , and troops from both Australia and New Zealand were at the forefront of the attack, and they suffered heavy casualties.To mark the occasion in Orkney, a contingent from the Kirkwall branch of the Royal British Legion led the remembrance ceremony, at the four Anzac war graves at St Olaf’s Cemetery, which was also attended by members of the Stromness branch of the Royal British Legion, and members of the Orkney branch of the Royal Naval Association.Kirkwall Legion president Eddy Ross carried out a service of remembrance at the graveside.Australian Orkney resident Suzanne Carter was asked to lay a wreath to mark the occasion. Also among those present was Janine Miller, we of Australian national Greg Miller who also lives in Orkney.This year the wreath was laid on the final resting place of –year–old Royal New Zealand Navy Volunteer Reserve pilot, LieutenantThomas Noel Bush, who was tragically killed on December , .Lt Bush’s Hawker Sea Hurricane fighter plunged from the sky above Kirkwall straight into the Peedie Sea — while, only yards away, people were in their homes, or going about their daily business.On that fateful day, Lt Bush arrived to pick up the aircraft and, following a few pre-flight checks, took to the air.However, within minutes witnesses heard the aircraft`s engine revving at high speed and, from a height of approximately ft, it ed straight down into the Peedie Sea, killing the pilot instantly.Local emergency services and personnel from HMS Sparrowhawk were quickly on the scene, but nothing could be done for the unfortunate pilot.Lt Bush’s body was recovered from the wreckage and he was buried, with full military honours, in St Olaf`s Cemetery, on the outskirts of Kirkwall, on December , .Kirkwall branch of the Royal British Legion chairman Dougie Manson said: “Those who died came from far and wide to serve their countries overseas, coming here today is the least we can do to remember them. It is important that we mark the sacrice they made.” vw, px"  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: cast your vote in pilot vessel poll
story: People in Orkney have the chance to select the name for the islands’ new pilot launch # currently under construction in Spain.The most recent of the Harbour Authority’s other pilot launches, the John Rae, was named after a successful public poll and the plan is to repeat the exercise in naming the new vessel, which arrives in Orkney in late August this year.A public vote opens today,  Wednesday May ,  which will determine the name that will grace the vessel’s hull. The online poll is available on Orkney Islands Council’s website www.orkney.gov.ukA shortlist has been drawn up by OIC Marine Services which features prominent figures from the county’s history, plus the name of a previous pilot launch:The design and build contract for the new -metre pilot vessel was secured after a competitive tendering exercise by Astilleros Armon S.A, which has its main base in Northern Spain.The vessel will join the two pilot launches currently operated by Marine Services. The naming ceremony is planned for September .Graham Sinclair, chairman of the council’s development and infrastructure committee, said: “Like the celebrated explorer John Rae, some fitting names from Orkney’s past feature on the shortlist for the new vessel and I would encourage folk to take part in the poll.“With harbour business thriving in Orkney, this is an opportune time to replace an ageing pilot launch with a more modern, capable, and reliable vessel. Like her predecessors, she will give us the capability to deliver a -hour, year-round pilotage service in the very challenging waters around Orkney. This greatly benefits the economy of our islands.“I look forward to the outcome of the vote and hope that as many folk as possible take this opportunity to choose the name for a vessel that will become a familiar sight in local waters.”As well as the online poll, you can send your preferred name from the shortlist by post to Pilot Vessel Poll, Harbour Authority Building, Old Scapa Rd, Scapa, Kirkwall KW SD. If you submit a postal vote, please include your name and phone number.The poll closes on Tuesday, May . A winner will be drawn from the votes for the most popular name, invited to take part in September’s naming ceremony and offered the opportunity of a family trip at a later date aboard the new pilot launch.Brian Archibald, Harbour Master and Head of Marine Services, Engineering and Transportation, said: “We look forward to the delivery and naming ceremony for our new pilot launch.“Orkney continues to benefit from a signicant upturn in harbour related activity, making it essential that we invest in the equipment and vessels necessary to deliver a safe and efficient service.“Our pilot launches play a vital role at the heart of our harbours operations. They enable marine pilots to embark and disembark from vessels heading to and from berths and anchorages within the Orkney Harbours area. These operations take place day and night in all weathers # the pilot launches need to be highly capable vessels built to high specications of sea keeping and reliability.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: european parliamentary elections postal vote reminder
story: newsEuropean Parliamentary Elections — Postal Vote ReminderApril ,  at : pm vw, px"  Voters wishing to get a postal vote for the forthcoming European Parliamentary Elections are being reminded that they need to apply by pm on May .To apply, contact the Electoral Registration Office on  or drop into their offices on , Broad Street, Kirkwall or by emailing ero@orkney.gov.ukPacks will be sent out from May  onwards and will contain three items — a ballot paper, aenvelope and a postal voting statement attached to a ballot paper envelope.Postal votes should be posted to reach the Council Offices no later than pm on May , polling day. However, postal votes can also be handed into polling stations and the Council Offices at School Place on the day of the election before pm.Around  per cent of Orkney#s electorate has a postal vote, meaning that they do not have to attend a polling station on polling day to vote.At this point in time, the UK will be holding elections to the European Parliament on Thursday, May  and arrangements have been put in place by Orkney Islands Council’s elections team, in line with local authorities across the country.Electors under the age of  will not be eligible to vote in this election.EU citizens living in Orkney are being contacted about additional paperwork they will need to completethey intend to vote in the county. European Parliament Voter Registration forms allow EU citizens to vote here, rather than in their home country and are being sent out this week to over  EU citizens currently resident in Orkney. Completed forms should be ed by pm on Tuesday May .Anyone who wishes to register to vote, vote by post, postal proxy or proxy, and has not already applied, can do so now by visiting the online service at #Register to Vote# on the GOV.UK website or by contacting the Electoral Registration Office on .For any other general queries in respect of the election, please contact the Election Office on .The deadlines for application are as follow:• Deadline for receiving applications for registration to vote — midnight on May • Deadline for receiving applications for postal votes — pm on May • Deadline for receiving applications for postal proxy votes — pm on May • Deadline for receiving applications for proxy votes — pm on May Anyone wanting to check their entry on the Register of Electors can also contact the Electoral Registration Office on the above number.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: ev charging fees set for to be introduced in may
story: Fees for using Orkney Islands Council’s electric vehicle chargers are set to be introduced next month.The move follows a public consultation in December last year and discussion with the Orkney EV Owners’ Group.OIC currently provides four rapid and  fast-medium chargers that are free-to-use at present.Charges will be brought in from Monday, May :Darren Richardson, the council’s head of infrastructure and strategic projects, said: “Our community is leading the way when it comes to EV uptake.“There are more than  EVs in Orkney – a higher percentage of vehicles on our roads are powered by electricity than anywhere  in Scotland.“Our network of chargers plays an important role in supporting this and we’re currently installing more chargers at a range of locations.“But the cost of providing this service increases as more and more drivers make the switch to EV ownership and make use of the chargers — and we’ve reached the point where we need to introduce fees for their use.”He added: “We believe many EV owners will support us in this and, more widely, the public have indicated a willingness to see new charges brought in for some of the services the council provides,this helps prevent cuts to frontline services.“Introducing fees for use of our EV chargers will assist with the running costs, including routine and reactive maintenance and electricity consumption.“We’ve worked with the local EV owners’ group in developing this set of charges and will trial these over the next  months. We will monitor what effect they have on use of our EV chargers and this will help us review the fees we set in future.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: ferry walkway repair could take months say oic
story: The passenger walkway used by foot passengers using the mv Hamnavoe could be out of action for months.The walkway at Stromness Ferry Terminal has suffered signicant damage, following a hydraulic system failure, meaning passengers have been boarding and disembarking the ferry through its car ramps.Orkney Islands Council owns and operates the walkway and the council says that the repair bill could be “substantial”.“It is important to find out what caused this — and this is being looked at, as is a full assessment of the repairs that will be needed,” Councillor Graham Sinclair said.“Repair work has started. But, given the damage, it’s going to take some time before the walkway is operational again.“Until we know the full extent of the work required, it’s dficult to say with certainty how long it will be out of action, but it could be a number of months.“We realise this will cause inconvenience for passengers and for NorthLink Ferries. We’ve kept the ferry company up to date and this will continue as the work progresses.“We won’t know the cost of the repair work until the full assessment is completed, but it could be substantial.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: kirkwall streets to reopen this week
story: Orkney Islands Council have confirmed that street closures in the centre of Kirkwall are due to come to an end, this week, as the first stage of the Places and Spaces project reaches completion.Broad Street, Castle Street and Albert Street have been closed to vehicles whilst major street works were carried out. With new surfacing laid over the last week, the council say that a short time will be required for the surface to cure, with the streets to reopen to traffic on Friday at the latest.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which include changes to the area at the bottom of the Strynd and top of Castle Street, as well as providing a new path to the War Memorial on the Kirk Green.With the initial phase of the project now completed, works will be suspended for the main summer season. Plans are for work to move to the entrance to Victoria Street in the autumn, being suspended again in December for Christmas shopping season.The Places and Spaces initiative was developed alongside community groups such as the Kirkwall and St Ola Community Council and the Kirkwall BID, who identied key areas of the town where it was felt improvements could be made. According to OIC, proposed improvements were the positively received by the Orkney community during a two-day consultation period, where  per cent of those who attended said they supported the proposals,  per cent were against and the rest were undecided.The Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative is a five-year heritage-based grant scheme which seeks to deliver sustainable improvements to the built heritage of the Kirkwall Conservation Area, in an effort to regenerate the centre of Kirkwall for the benefit of local communities and businesses, as well as to attract visitors. The scheme has been running since July  and will conclude in June.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: northlink takes the lead on reducing waste
story: Plastic items — including glasses, cups, lids, teaspoons and portion pots — have either been removed or replaced with sustainable alternatives. Ethical beverage supplier Ethyco now supplies  per cent compostable single-use cups and lids across NorthLink Ferries’ food and drink outlets.Ceramic catering pots have also replaced plastic pots and reusable polycarbonate beakers have replaced wax-lined disposable drinking cups. The replacement beakers have led to approximately , disposable cups and , plastic lids being removed from the waste stream per annum.More than , polystyrene food trays used in children#s meal packages have been replaced by a plant-based and  per cent compostable alternative.Seumas Campbell, Serco’s customer service director for NorthLink Ferries, said: “Looking after the natural environment is such an important part of the service we provide. So we are passionate about minimising our impact on the world around us. The steps we have taken to remove single-use plastics are very positive and we will keep looking for more opportunities to reduce our environmental footprint.”One Stop Waste Solutions, an Aberdeen-based recycling and waste services company, has seconded that NorthLink Ferries has already met the criteria for the  ban on general commercial waste sent to landfill.Craig Donoghue, managing director of the organisation added: “We have been working closely with NorthLink Ferries since , and in that time have seen a sustained effort to recycle and reduce waste. In particular, this commitment has peaked since  coinciding with ‘the Attenborough effect’. The company’s ongoing commitment will continue to lead the way in the journey towards zero waste.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
